episodeTitle: Led by a Bell's Sound! Tale of the Great Warrior and the Explorer!
description: Wyper narrates a flashback revealing the 400-year-old history of Mont Blanc Noland and Kalgara. When the Shandia tribe falls victim to Tree Fever, Noland arrives and saves the village by curing the disease, beginning an unlikely friendship that will echo through the ages.

events.title: Wyper Begins Narrating the Flashback
events.description: As Enel continues his destruction of Skypiea, Wyper begins to narrate the 400-year-old history of Mont Blanc Noland and Kalgara, explaining the origins of the conflict between Shandia and Skypieans.
events.significance: Sets up the crucial backstory that explains the entire Skypiea conflict and the importance of the Golden Bell.

events.title: Kalgara's First Appearance
events.description: The flashback begins 400 years in the past, introducing Kalgara, the feared 'Demon of Shandora,' as he attacks intruders on Jaya. He throws a massive anchor at a fleeing ship and jumps aboard to attack the crew, demonstrating his fearsome reputation.
events.significance: Introduction of one of the most important characters in Skypiea's history, whose legacy shapes the entire arc.

events.title: Mont Blanc Noland's First Appearance
events.description: Admiral Mont Blanc Noland is introduced as a fearless explorer and botanist. When his crew runs out of food, he dives into the ocean and catches a massive fish to feed them, showcasing his strength and dedication to his crew.
events.significance: Introduction of the legendary explorer whose story becomes central to the Skypiea arc and whose descendant Cricket appears in the modern timeline.

quotes.text: The ship was out of food.
quotes.speaker: Crew member
quotes.context: Before Noland dives to catch fish for the crew

events.title: Noland Hears the Golden Bell
events.description: During a storm, Noland hears a distant bell ringing through the tempest. He writes about it in his logbook, marking the first time he becomes aware of Shandora's Golden Bell.
events.significance: The bell becomes a central symbol of the friendship between Noland and Kalgara, and its sound guides Noland to Jaya.

events.title: Tree Fever Plague Revealed
events.description: The Shandia village is devastated by Tree Fever, a deadly disease with a 90% fatality rate. The dying priest Chiya, covered in green stains, declares that the village is cursed and demands that a girl be sacrificed to the gods to lift the curse.
events.significance: Introduces the crisis that brings Noland and Kalgara together, and demonstrates the desperation of the Shandia people.

quotes.text: Shandia is cursed! To save the village, a girl must be offered to the Sacrificial Altar!
quotes.speaker: Chiya
quotes.context: The dying priest's proclamation about the plague

events.title: Seto's Introduction
events.description: Noland's crew discovers Seto, a young Shandian man suffering from Tree Fever, trying desperately to scrape the green stains off his arm with a rock. He laments that he wanted to become a great warrior like Kalgara but is now dying.
events.significance: Seto becomes the first person Noland saves, demonstrating the explorer's medical knowledge and compassion.

quotes.text: I wanted to be like him one day, but instead I'm going to die like this.
quotes.speaker: Seto
quotes.context: Seto lamenting his fate from Tree Fever

events.title: Noland Diagnoses Tree Fever
events.description: Dr. Honner, Noland's ship doctor, diagnoses Seto's condition as Tree Fever. Noland immediately orders his crew to gather Conine from the Kona Tree to treat Seto and prepare to cure the entire village.
events.significance: Demonstrates Noland's botanical expertise and foreshadows his ability to save the Shandia people.

events.title: Mousse at the Sacrificial Altar
events.description: Mousse, Kalgara's daughter and the most beautiful woman on Jaya, is brought by boat to the Sacrificial Altar to be offered to the snake god Kashigami. A priest delivers a prayer as she is tied to the altar, willing to sacrifice herself to save her people.
events.significance: Establishes the desperate measures the Shandia are taking and sets up the confrontation between Noland and Kalgara.

events.title: Kashigami the Snake God Appears
events.description: The giant snake Kashigami, worshipped as a deity by the Shandia, emerges from the water and hovers over Mousse, preparing to devour her as a sacrifice. The massive serpent is hundreds of meters long with blue scales and yellow eyes.
events.significance: Introduction of the creature that symbolizes the Shandia's desperate faith and sets up Noland's heroic intervention.

events.title: Noland Kills Kashigami and Saves Mousse
events.description: Just as Kashigami is about to devour Mousse, Mont Blanc Noland jumps into the water, climbs the sacrificial altar, and beheads the giant snake with his sword, killing it instantly. The Shandia people are horrified that their god has been slain.
events.significance: This pivotal moment saves Mousse's life but creates a massive cultural conflict, as Noland has killed what the Shandia worship as a god. This sets up the central tension between Noland and Kalgara.

quotes.speaker: Mont Blanc Noland
quotes.context: Noland's declaration as he saves Mousse from Kashigami

events.title: Kalgara Attacks Noland
events.description: Outraged by the profanation of their sacred ritual and the killing of Kashigami, Kalgara swims to the altar and attacks Noland. Noland introduces himself as an explorer from the North Sea and tries to defend his actions, but Kalgara refuses to listen.
events.significance: The first confrontation between Noland and Kalgara, establishing their initial antagonism that will later transform into deep friendship.

quotes.text: I am an explorer from the North Sea!
quotes.speaker: Mont Blanc Noland
quotes.context: Noland trying to explain himself to the attacking Kalgara

events.title: Noland Promises to Cure the Village
events.description: Despite the hostility from the Shandia, Noland promises to cure the village of Tree Fever by sunset, offering to accomplish what the sacrifice was meant to achieve without taking any lives. He asks for time to prove himself.
events.significance: This promise becomes the foundation of trust between Noland and the Shandia people, and demonstrates Noland's unwavering belief in science over superstition.

quotes.speaker: Mont Blanc Noland
quotes.context: Noland's promise to save the village

themes.description: The episode explores the conflict between scientific knowledge and religious belief, as Noland's medical expertise challenges the Shandia's faith-based understanding of their plague.
themes.symbolism: Kashigami represents blind faith and tradition, while Noland's Conine cure represents rational, scientific thinking.
culturalReferences: The story parallels historical conflicts between explorers and indigenous peoples

themes.description: Despite good intentions, Noland's actions are seen as sacrilegious by the Shandia, highlighting how different cultural perspectives can create conflict even when both sides mean well.
themes.symbolism: The beheading of Kashigami symbolizes the destruction of sacred beliefs, even when done to save lives.

themes.description: Both Mousse's willingness to sacrifice herself and Noland's determination to save strangers demonstrate different forms of selflessness and duty to others.
themes.symbolism: The Sacrificial Altar represents the lengths people will go to protect their communities.

themes.description: Noland's refusal to accept human sacrifice, even in the face of cultural tradition, emphasizes the universal value of human life.
themes.symbolism: Saving Seto first demonstrates that every individual life matters, not just the 'beautiful' sacrifice.

characterSpotlights.development: Introduced as a fearless explorer, skilled botanist, and compassionate leader who values human life above all cultural traditions. His actions set the stage for his legendary friendship with Kalgara.
keyActions: Catches a massive fish to feed his hungry crew
Hears the Golden Bell through a storm
Promises to cure the entire village
quotes: I will lift the curse and cure the disease, but I need time!

characterSpotlights.development: Introduced as the feared 'Demon of Shandora,' a fierce warrior who initially sees Noland as a threat to his people's traditions and beliefs. His conflict with Noland will evolve into one of One Piece's most touching friendships.
keyActions: Allows his daughter to be sacrificed to save the village

characterSpotlights.development: Kalgara's daughter demonstrates the courage and selflessness of the Shandia people by accepting her role as a sacrifice to save her village from the plague.
keyActions: Accepts being offered as a sacrifice to Kashigami
Is saved by Noland at the last moment

characterSpotlights.development: Wyper narrates the flashback, connecting the ancient history to the present-day conflict with Enel and explaining the importance of the Golden Bell and Shandora to the Shandia people.
keyActions: Narrates the flashback of Noland and Kalgara

mangaDifferences.difference: The episode adapts chapters 286-288, covering the beginning of the Noland and Kalgara flashback. The anime adds extended scenes of Noland's journey and the storm sequence.

trivia.fact: This episode marks the first appearance of Mont Blanc Noland, whose descendant Mont Blanc Cricket helped the Straw Hats reach Skypiea in episodes 144-146.

sources.title: Mont Blanc Noland - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: Tree Fever is based on real diseases that devastated indigenous populations when explorers introduced new pathogens, though in this case Noland brings the cure rather than the disease.
Kashigami's descendant, Nola, appears in the present-day Skypiea arc and resembles the ancient snake god in appearance.
The episode's title references the Golden Bell, which becomes the ultimate symbol of Noland and Kalgara's friendship in episodes 188-189.
Noland's voice actor Hōchū Ōtsuka also voices Jiraiya in Naruto, giving both characters a similarly gruff but kind-hearted vocal quality.
